reviewText:
+ Terrain control
+ Cute, but not annoyingly so, characters

- Poor sound. VO sounds like someone had some awful series of accidents in audacity.
- Poor camera (and camera controls). Feels like a poorly adapted port from a mobile game; no zoom, quite clunky in general.
- Lack of variety. Limited missions, characters, powers, and reasons to actually play.

More or less feels like a dodgy phone adaptation of Black & White without any of the qualities that made B&W engaging, fun, or challenging.

reviewText: I wanted to love this game, it could've been everything I'd been yearning for since Populous: The Beginning but unfortunately these were shoes too big to fill. Controls felt minimal and very clunky and the aesthetics of the game looked rather primitive. The gameplay itself lacked depth with nearly every aspect whether it being construction, units, powers or terraforming almost as if it was an iOS game. Idol Hands has potential but stumbles with every feature that makes God games great, I would sadly not recommend it.

reviewText:
Please read completely before making full judgment. The TL;DR is at the bottom.

Before I purchased this game, I saw that the top reviews were negative ones. However, I liked the screenshots and description, and I am fairly open-minded with low expectations, so I figured I'd give it a shot. I think one of the biggest problems is that people are going into this expecting more than what it is. The popular tags really should include Casual".

Overall
date: I liked it. It is a God game
recommended: but on a Casual scale. It does not reach the grandiosity of many other God games. I can understand how there are so many negative reviews
hoursPlayed: especially the ones made on release day at a higher price point. Considering Pocket Games planned to
voteText: and did release
votesHelpful: I think the design was targeting mobile from the beginning. This game is limited in scope
commentsCount: etc. I will go into it more later.\n\nI have played the game to full completion
column16: including all achievements. It took around 5 hours to complete
column17: and then another 5 or so to grind the "Tree Expert" achievement. So
column18:
it is a short game. Does that make it bad? Not really. I like being able to complete games. It's perfect for people like me that don't have much free time due to work and family. I completed it over 3 nights.

My Detailed Opinions
The characters have a unique design to them. They are charming
column19: but they are also fun to set on fire or strike down with lightning. They make noises and exclamations
column20: but it's nothing complex.\n\nThe terrain design is well done. There aren't a large number of textures
column21: but they fit the overall feel. The islands themselves include little scenic bits that might go unnoticed
column22: such as a variety of flowers
column23: ferns and other undergrowth. Being able to alter it is also nice. It's not as detailed of alterations as something like From Dust
column25: but it's still there.\n\nThe game is not that difficult. Due to the limited size of the playing field
column26: there is only so much that can be done. During the campaign
column27: there are caps on the number of each type of Furling other than Warrior. Only the sandbox allows more.\n\nEach campaign "level" is just a variation of another. Since there are only 5 types of Furlings and just a handful of God powers
column28: the only thing that makes each different is the island configuration
column31: I swear the AI starts cheating more. On the final level
column32: it was like the end of days for my side. I was spending quite a bit of time putting out fires
column33: fixing the terrain and creating replacement Furlings. I don't see how the AI was able to throw so many meteors when I had the same number of Priests and couldn't do the same.\n\nThe controls take some getting used to. However
column34: once you've used them a few times
column36:
some of the things mentioned in older reviews have been addressed. Check out the discussions to see what the developer has said.

The key features are very deceptive. Here's a breakdown:
Play God... : It sounds like they can be commanded. They can't. The description counters with "your people will live their own lives". Even the Warriors go all willy nilly when they get near the enemy. In almost all war strategy games I've played
column38: my troops go after it. These guys use the Totem as more of a compass marker than a destination.\nShape a beautiful... : Yes
column40: calling it a "world" makes it sound massive. So does the "take over the world" wording in the main description. In reality
column41: each mission is a relatively small island or pair of islands (enemy on one side
column42: you on the other). The only way to make it any bigger is to keep leveling it out into the water. But in no way is it global domination like it sounds.\nFeel the power... : Sorry
column43: it's not "massive" natural disasters. They are fairly weak. Even the volcanoes can be countered. They are short-lived and have a short projectile range. Just flatten them and use Rain. Anything destroyed can be quickly rebuilt. Earthquake can only take out buildings in a close range. It's not as destructive as a real one. A well-targeted meteor might take out a building and set some on fire
column44: but it doesn't cause a massive crater or such.\nPlay the game... : There really isn't multiple strategies other than mixing up which disasters you use and when/where Warriors are sent. But
column46: there isn't any real replayability like bigger RTS games.\nIn the description
column47:
it says this:

learn skills to eventually forming an immense fighting force that you can unleash upon your enemy’s population to wipe them out
They don't learn anything as they are just created as one of 5 types (and only 1 is a fighter)
column48: "immense" is not an appropriate term for a standing army of 10-20 warriors
column49:
and the enemy's population is just as limited as yours. Wiping them out isn't that difficult.

The Quick Review
+ Pleasant
column51:
graphics
+ Terrain design and control
+ Charming characters
+ Not too difficult

they sometimes build too far away.

- That stupid "Tree Expert" achievement. It's so out of place compared to the others. It's so annoying that I made a guide for it.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=658881594

column54:
I had to leave it on the medium setting to run smoothly.
- Game gets laggy on sandbox once there are a lot of Furlings and trees. Loading my Tree Expert save would even cause it to go Not Responding for a while.

Final Say
Even with the questionable and negative points

reviewText: Idol Hands takes a godly amount of time to actually start getting interesting and that's only if you can survive the dodgy voice acting during the unskippable tutorial which, let's face it, sounds like it was recorded from a tin can connected to some string. The fact that in a game where you literally play a god, it was bizzare that my actions were limited by mana and subsequently I never actually felt like I had any meaningful input and didn't feel empowered as a god. All this and a bizarre choice of camera controls all added up to a pretty boring experience.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sTQ0wm-NMNc

reviewText:
I cannot recommend Idol Hands to any gamers, to be fair its not a bad game. It just has too many handicaps that prevent it from being enjoyable, first is the Scrolling the menus and the way the camera moves is very clunky making the game frustrating at some points. The enemy AI will never use his god powers to really disrupt your expansion making you feel pretty much unchallenged at almost every point.

Now if your still kind of on the fence because it is one of the few god games on the market and you have played Populous and Black & White to death and you just really want another God Game. Well there is some hope here for you, why it is certianly not the best game it does have some features that I do like, First of all the ability to Morph the landscape is awesome despite the wierd looking aninmation of it doing so. It does have an interesting Desciple" System for your followers. After a few levels you do get some apocalyptic powers which do help make the game feel like you are more useful than just a tool to the bloody demanding furlings.

I would really like to see if they make a second Idol Hands

reviewText:
So this is Idol Hands.  With all the hype over at GMG, i was expecting something huge, something they failed to deliver on.  Its not bad, don't get me wrong, its just not Black and White 2 great.  Those are some big shoes to fill, i get that, but the developer could have tried a wee bit harder.  After reading some of the negative comments, they all share the same gripes, which are also mine.

Postive:
its a god game, with volcanoes
you can Smite them rats into oblivion
terrain control( it is a god game, right?)

Negative:
camera control, you have none really.  No rotation, no zoom/unzoom, just overhead and action. another reviewer says the right mouse button rotates, tried it, it didnt work for me.
Length, its short, and a good portion of the game is spent in the tutorial that you cannot bypass
its just not grand.  you get 50 population, with that you have to figure out how to divide them into 5 catagories.
no way to speed up the action
you start with a set score and it counts down when you start, no way to recoup the score ( so far the only reason to replay, to beat the score)

Bottom line:

I miss watching your monster change according to his actions, i miss the way LionHead made you feel playing  B&W, its scope, the ability to help your villages, the good/evil dynamic.  This is what made B&W great, what made it epic.  Idol hands cant deliver on that premise, maybe with a well tuned expansion it can, but now...no.  After the hype at GMG i felt they were trying to make promises they failed to deliver on.  As the 1st venture for Greenman loaded, they need to learn that people will only pay for a short, flawed game if the story and the game dynamics pick up the slack.  IH doesnt get there at its current cost.  It is fun, it is simple to learn, and if they continue to develope the game, it can be what its trying to be, so i recommend it for a sale or a coupon purchase as a casual game.

7/10
kids 5+

reviewText:
Feb 2016

UPDATE: I can easily recommend the game now, as they fixed a lot of the issues I had a year ago.  It's also only $5 as opposed to $20.  Changing my review from negative to positive.

---

Feb 2015

Oh, how I wanted to recommend it.  On the plus side, it’s a god game that lets you reshape the land so that your furlings can construct their own structures as well as cast powers like earthquakes and volcanoes (similar to Populous).  On the surface, this sounds great!  On the other, there are some really odd things about this game that make me scratch my head in wonder as to what the developers were thinking.  There are no time controls, no WASD or arrow key camera movement, no zooming (there is a fixed bird’s eye view), holding in right mouse click and moving the mouse up and down (not left or right oddly) rotates the camera, no HP bars above buildings, your score decreases as you play (rushing you into beating it more quickly), and more.  As far as I can tell, there are eight levels on the campaign menu and no skirmish modes.  The inclusion of the latter would have given the game some replay value and could have made it worth $20 despite these short-sided gameplay mechanics.  As it stands, it just doesn't do enough to justify that price tag (in my opinion).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHhXcB6bsCg
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Idol Hands may have been promoted as 'the god game that people have been waiting for' but it just doesn't seem ready. When you compare it to classics such as Populous and Black & White. it doesn’t match up in terms of depth or challenge. It’s a nice little way to pass some time if you’ve only got an hour to spare and don’t want to get involved with a video game that’s too absorbing, but if you’re looking for the next big thing in the genre unfortunately you’re not likely to find it here.

However, it seems as if the developers are quite active when it comes to managing both their first release and the community. Perhaps if they continue adding features and manage to release a multiplayer mode, the mixed reception the game has received so far will improve there may be some life in Idol Hands yet. But at the moment it still has a way to go: they may be better off reducing the £14.99 price-tag and marketing it as a casual game, rather than Populous’ successor.

A full review of Idol Hands can be found here: http://1001up.com/2015/04/09/review-idol-hands/

reviewText:
My Let's Play:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6_DXSlmHQ1U

Quick Impressions: Idol Hands is a God Game that features terrain deformation as a requirement for growing your village of Furlings as well as being used offensively/defensively (whichever way works best strategically) against the opposing God/village.

Easily the Terrain Deformation is the stand-out feature in this game and is handled remarkably well and is graphically impressive. You'll need to use these powers to level land so that you're farmers can cultivate crops and feed your population so that you can produce more workers (wood/metal/priests) and warriors to protect your village. As you level the land around you, the border of your colony will slowly grow larger as your workers build new buildings automatically.

Another plus that I really enjoyed but doesn't really change much of the game was clicking on the minimap and zooming out super far and you are presented with a landscape that is very reminiscent of the view enjoyed in Act Raiser. Again, not the biggest thing but I really liked it.

The big negatives that I have for the game is the SUPER long mandatory tutorial sections (1+ hour(s)) and the inability to speed up the game. Everything in the game runs at 1x speed, always. So the early part of the game is rather boring because you don't even have all of your spells yet.

Overall though, the game is very charming and family friendly.

Recommended

reviewText:
Well, nothing like Populous or Black and White. Sorry, but this is a mobile game.

My brief experience with this game was like this:
- Select highest resolution, start game.
- Graphics are not bad, but not great either.
- Tutorial 1 is fine, similar to other god games, but your focus is always on the middle of the screen, not on your mouse cursor. Bizarre, but ok.
- Begin tutorial 2; lowered terrain and, by doing that, accidentally destroyed one of my farms.
- Started getting this annoying message saying my villagers didn't have enough to eat.
- Tried to level lots of terrain around the villagers, so that they could build another farm (they're supposed to do that on their own). Didn't work.
- Created a couple of farmers to see if *they* would create a farm. Didn't work.
- Leveled more terrain, created more farmers, create some woodcutters and waited.
- Nothing... only that stupid message saying I didn't have enough farms.
- During this whole time since the beggining of the tutorial, I was watching my points DECREASE by the second. It works like a timer, trying to force you to persue your goals. Hated it.
- Hate it so much I stopped playing and came here to tell you this. I won't open this game ever again.
- Paid R$ 19,00 (about USD 5,00). Didn't hurt, but could have bought a better game.

Sorry guys, I didn't like it. I won't ask for a refund - I wanted to find out how this game was and I guess I did... But I don't feel like playing it again. I'm better off playing Dungeons 2: it's not really a god game, but it gives you the feeling you are actually the sh*t. In Idol Hands I feel I'm more of an observer who can raise terrain. Pretty lame, IMHO.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-M4OvJdu_D8

This game was clearly sponsored by the Pro-Hurricane lobbies.  Rain doesn't do any damage, all it does is put out fires and make your crops more useful.

FACT:  HURRICANES KILL MORE PEOPLE EVERY YEAR THAN ANY OTHER NATURAL DISASTER.  Volcanos do not beat rain, rain is the most powerful force on Earth.

Despite this poor design choice the game is very fun.... for a couple of hours and then you realize how repeatitive the campaign is.  It's always playing against the same enemy using the exact same kind of tactics doing the exact same thing.  You begin to realize how shallow exactly the game is in design.

The campaign is really long, but eventually you will be wondering when will it end as you face the same enemy and same objective over and over and over and over.

I bought this game because I grew up with Populous and was a huge fan of Baldies.  But this game doesn't have enough diverse options for play.  The population caps on various classes mean you will max out every single class and work towards playing in one manner.

reviewText:
Loved the action in this game and really cool graphics - cute but firey. A real darker underside to what, on the surface, looks like a really cutesy game.

Pros:
Its got great graphics
The AI is really sweet
Love the earthquake and volcano effects - we need more of those
Great price for such a beautiful game
Seem to be really engaging with the community
Great for the young ones in the family as well as us older players


Cons:
Not enough content, but i did read they are working on more content, lets see what the future brings...
Need the camera movement fixing

So addictive i think i am going to miss lunch and dinner...off to carry on playing before work starts :)
Oh - and that old guy's voice....really?

Tips:
I found that you need to re-organize your groups so that in the beginning you have loads of wood cutters and iron miners, but towards the end you don't need so many and you need more soldiers. Given you are limited by total Furlings, i had to kill off some Miners in the end! Painful....but necessary ... in God We Trust.

reviewText: The God game genre has seen its fair share of flops; Idol Hands tries very hard not to be one of the many to set aside. Idol Hands is a game that will appeal to casual audiences but will not impress them by any means. The features of Idol Hands are very few, and variety is lacking. Once the initial interest in the game’s single focus mechanic has been played out, you are left with a disappointing hurry up and wait game.\n\nTo see the full review head over to http://www.modvive.com/2015/02/20/idol-hands-review-playing-in-the-dirt/
voteText: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game was fairly interesting at first.  As the tutorial walks you through your new powers, I was feeling like this would have a fun level of complexity to it.
However, the game quickly becomes repetative and tedious with the end game of each level taking an inordinately long time to finish.
The game strategy is basically choosing what order to build your 5 types of units in, most with a hard cap on the total amount you can have, and managing when to use your mana, as in using a cheap power now, or saving for a more powerful attack.  You have no control over the placement of your buildings or actions of your workers and very limited control over your soldiers.
The game is also fairly short, I beat it in about 5 hours, maybe less.  About a third of this time was spent more or less just waiting for my soldiers to finish taking out the enemy's town with virtually no resistance.
There is a sandbox mode once you are finished, but other than using my earthmoving powers to draw a few funny shapes into the dirt, it got boring very quickly.
This is not a bad game, but I would not recommend buying it.

reviewText:
Im glad i didn't spend as much as i would have on steam. This game isn't horrible but it's a very basic game. It doesnt have much to it. It's a pretty simple style RTS game. I do like the concept of it. Being a God of a little tribe and being able to shape the lands to make it easier for the tribes to grow... However the AI is a bit slow reacted and bland. The game doesnt exactly have a story either. It's more or less other tribes are on islands and you need to grow and invade them. Like i said the AI takes some time to respond to attack orders but the game needs a lot of work. This game has alot of potential if the developers took their time and added more to it.

Now as i look the developers are taking feed back to the game. In March 2015 they're going to update it and add features to make it a bit better.

I personally would like to see a bit more difficulty, more macro sets, more builds of characters, more tech. (catapults, etc) Maybe even being able to shift all your mana and making a mighty hero to serve.

Again as i previously stated the game needs work, but it's not horrible. If the developers stick to their game like the update says and even continues to add future updates then this game would be great. It has a lot of potential

reviewText:
The short and skinny...

PROS

Decent graphics, but that's subjective.
Devs are active in the forums.
Devs said in a post they plan on adding more content/features. Some may be game enhancements (camera, zoom, speed settings), but extra content such as new lands and spells will most likely be DLC. So this is more of a nuetral" variable
date:
not necessarily a "pro."

CONS

limited "God actions."  You can raise

column42:
at best for what you get out of it.

You will finish campaign in less than 3 hours. There just isn't much to do in the game.  There's no variety. It feels like it is still early access w/ such a lack of content. It's like they tried to compensate for the lack of content by creating a tutorial/campaign. I'd much rather have a shorter campaign and have more stuff to do.

RECOMMENDATION

Hold off for now and see how the game develops. It has potential

reviewText:
Well gave it a go, wish people would have waited for DEV's to update and when they did, update their review.  I have been playing games for years and this one shocked me.  After doing some research on the studio too, this is pretty awsome for a first game.  I have the attention span of a merecat so to keep me going on a game for a while is usually a difficult task.

-Graphics look great and are limited to options which can be why it runs so stable.

-Tutorial is excelent and the map navigation can be done easily now.

-Voice acting is silly but the are tiny creatures, have you ever heard one in real life to compare :)

-Hearing the screams of the enemy is comical

-Very creative terrain modification.  Love the Hand Of God effect!

Overall i must say, Home run for your first game and will be looking for further titles.  I hope that people who reviewed the original version will update their review.

reviewText:
Short but fun godgame with intuitive controls and full tutorial built into your campaign. Could be something a lot better with more built onto their foundation. Management, worship and combat are all very basic however and you don't have direct control over where buildings are placed, though the ai does build with it's purpose as a priority.

+WASD camera controls
+Terraforming
+UI built for purpose, everthing is conveniently displayed and accessible

-The slow pace of the advisor overlays can be an annoyance.
-Other than choosing which class to create and when, the village is autonomous

reviewText:
*Note* I bought this game on sale for 1.74, I don't think I would pay much more for it, but it's worth the 1.74:)
Summary:
Basicly you're a god, and you need magic to do things.
You get magic in 2 ways, more followers, priests (max 5).
besides that you can tell some followers to get a job to get resources, which allows you to tell some other followers to become soldiers.
Magic + soldiers = win.

The good:
Quite fun
Looks decent, not great though

The bad:
All you really do is cast some magic spells, be it raise or lower land, or throw a meteor.
Controls a bit weird and need some getting used to.

reviewText: This finally works on Linux based computers. Yay! It is a very enjoyable game. I think the little furlings are so adorable. Totally worth the $5 I paid for the game. No downsides. Tutorial is excellent. Main game is wonderful. I find this game relaxing as it gives me a sense of control in my otherwise uncontrollable life! :D So buy it & enjoy!
